Epidemic Breaks Out
AmongFreshman Class
Twenty three freshmen have
been to the Health Clinic since
Tuesday night complaining of
nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, chills
and body aches. The Health
Clinic is unsure as to the cause
of this epidemic. In an attempt
to identitfy the ailment, the
Health Clinic has asked that any
students experiencing these
please stop by the clinic
sympto
to fill out a questionnaire.
As in any case of multiple
illnesses of this nature, food is a
possible suspect. "We're still not
sure if it's the food or if it's a
virus that a lot of people who all
live together got at the same
time," said Joan Rehner, Direc-

tor of Student Health Services.
Rehner said that the majority of
the 23 people who are ill had
lasagna at dinner Tuesday night
in the Freshman cafeteria, but
right now the lasagna is not the
most likely suspect."One person
had nine helpings of lasagna and
didn't get sick, and another, who
was sick, said he didn't even eat
in the cafeteria."
In order to better investigate the matter, Rehner also asks
all those who ate the lasagna on
Tuesday night, but who did not
experience any of the symptoms, to please stop by the
Health Clinic and fill out a
questionnaire.

Towson Frat Charter Revoked
Towson State University has revoked the charter of the
Alpha Lambda Omega Fraternity following the accidental death
of a pledge.
According to the Evening Sun, three pledges were beginning "Hell Week" when the fatal accident occurred. On Sunday,
March 28, the three pledges involved attended an outdoor meeting until 3 a.m., were taken to Loch Raven and then instructed to
appear for breakfast at 7 a.m. on Monday.
After Monday's classes, the group met at 8 p.m. to recite
fraternity history and do pushups until 9 p.m., when they were
dressed up to acquire the signatures of former fraternity members. The accident occurred at 2:40 a.m. on 1-83. The driver was
killed; the two passengers are in good condition.
Towson's Alpha Lambda Omega Fraternity was not
supposed to hold the meeting on Sunday night, due to an earlier
suspension.
Other past hazing activities included the pledges eating
mounds of food covered with tabasco sauce while having their
bands tied behind their backs. Another rite was the forced eating
of ice cream covered with salt'and pepper. According to the
Evening Sun, one Hopkins alumnus remembered running pledges
through "the student pub naked."
In a similar incident, Western Maryland College recently
suspended their Delta Pi Alpha Fraternity after a pledge was
paddled and forced to drink liquor. The freshman required
treatment at the Carroll County General Hospital.

Of American Women,Blacks
BY STEVEN FEDER
Addressing an apparently
sympathetic audience of 100 in
the Glass Pavilion on Monday
night, U.S. Congresswoman
Shirley Chisholm (D—N.Y.)
drew applause for her description of and views on the roles
of women and blacks in American society. Her speech broadly
considered problems of discrimination against women and blacks
and enunciated general postures
for these groups which she
deemed helpful to their progress.
Organizers of the event
sponsored by the Black Students' Union (BSU) and the M.
Carey Thomas Women's Center
were satisfied with the attendance although they continue to
be concerned with the degree
of general apathy at Hopkins.
Chisholm attributed the current rapid erosion of gains in
equality for blacks and women
to the prevalence of discrimination and a lack of concern on
the part of those satisfied with
the status quo.
She pronounced racism the
"bugaboo of America" and said,
"Racism is inherent in the
bloodstream of this nation. . .
and makes it vulnerable to
attacks from opponents both
within and without this country." She said the "color line"
will continue to be a problem,
and class differences will become
an increasingly serious cause of
division.
Chisholm enumerated the
disregard for blacks and women
she saw in President Reagan's
budget cutting. She did not
detail specific goals of activism;
however, her intent was clearly
to advocate greater involvement
in programs with the stated goal
of equalizing opportunity. such
as Affirmative Action, school

busing, Title IX education requirements,
Chisholm encouraged the
audience to take a more active
role in advocating women's and
blacks' issues and suggested
greater black participation in
predominantly white feminist
organizations even when their
views are not entirely in harmony. She stressed that her
listeners should accept that
differences between people will
always exist, and a proper
personal goal was to express
individual priorities in a pluralistic group.
The speaker maintained that
the concern of Americans both
black and white should be more
consistent in responding to the
plight of repressed foreign nationals. She mentioned Ethiopians not allowed to remain in
this country because the State
Department declared them no
long_er in danger in their own
country, and contrasted them
with Hungarian and Polish refugees also fleeing Communist
countries, who were allowed to
stay. She also mentioned the
restriction of the entrance of
Haitian refugees into this country because the State Department does not regard their flight
as political while Amnesty International does.

David Organ, events chairman of the BSU, admonished
general "student apathy. . .of
epidemic proportions." He said
the BSU will use "any means
necessary to alleviate this. ..and
to make students start thinking
critically and analytically about
the functioning of this country."
Women's Center president
Laura Rosenthal also criticized a
deficient level of student activism: "[From the, attendance at
the address] it's obvious that
people support women's rights
and the rights of blacks. These
people must recognize the need
to organize as well as to attend
such functions."

of guilt upon those who do not attend

once said (N-L, April 2), "The poor

of guilt upon those who do not attend

and student plays?"
Samuel Johnson once said that

everyone wants to toot their own horn.

Mr. Writing Seminars read the story about
his grandmother that he wrote for your
seminar, and Steve Dixon's seminar, and
Ralph Lombreglia's seminar.
